ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned many things in this course.  As someone who is quite a theater novice, I learned almost everything under the sun such as movement, acting, dance, and the mind of a director.  I really appreciated how welcome this course made me feel given most of the other students were well-versed in theater.
A broad look at theatre from various perspectives and insight into which areas I might be interested in pursuing further, upon introduction to them.
looking at theater through multiple aspects. how to reflect and critique. what the THST program offers
None
General survey of the theater studies department and its faculty
Insight into many many different facets of performance we received valuable instruction from several different faculty members.
Got an overall sense of the theater dept's professors and course offerings
I have a wide scope of what qualifies as performance, and the significance of the different varieties of performances. I feel like I also understand the theater and performance industry better.

This is a GREAT introductory theater class. Each week is a different guest lecturer from the TAPS department/Drama School, so you get a really broad introduction to the field and get to hear from experts in all areas of the field -- everything from directing panels to avant garde/surrealism to playwriting and more.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved the structure of the course.  Bringing in new people each class kept me engaged and eager to come to next week's class.  The quizzes were quite tough and asked for more specific answers than I hoped they would, but I learned how to study for them over time.  My only other wish was that Professor Brooks had one class to himself, as I think he has a lot to offer.
very strong in showing the diversity of theater. I do think that the class has improved in racial inclusivity, but theres still more work to be done. Quizzes were unexpectedly difficult.
disorganized with little continuity between classes

Strengths: Getting to meet/talk to many TAPS professors. Getting to see a show.

Weaknesses: The class is really boring, you really don't learn much, the grading is pretty harsh for no reason. There are quizzes from stuff that only Hal knows, very minute stuff that does not teaches you anything.

Strengths: You get to meet a lot of theater and performance studies majors (or generally people interested). 
Weaknesses: Didnt really learn much, most lectures ended up being somewhat problematic.

I enjoyed the guest lecturers and how they are people currently working in the fields they were lecturing about. I felt as if this course gave a great preview to different courses available within the TAPS major and the people teaching those courses. I have no major critiques about this class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Great 111 course!
I'd recommend this to anyone remotely interested in performing arts.   I found it very accommodating to people of all levels.

A really great course for first year theatre majors, since it introduces you to faculty members, which can help you know which people you want to seek out/avoid in the rest of the theatre classes you take here.
Yes, great course to take if you want to learn all aspects of theater. Definitely more for actor director types then designers.
not unless you have to
Honestly, I don't think anyone should take this class unless you're decided on the major. I think even for the major, the class is pretty useless.

I would recommend it only to students considering the Theater and Performance Studies major. This course is structured so that students can meet many professors in the TAPS department and decide which ones they would like to work with in future classes. For non-TAPS majors, this can be interesting but not especially helpful.
If you are a TAPS major (or prospective major), you dont really have a choice. Otherwise, probably not.
Only if a THST major- better performance courses are available

Yes! I think it gave an intriguing theoretical overview to theater and performance. I feel as though I have a great understanding of the "why" we do theater. I think this course is interesting for people with little experience with theater and majors alike.
Absolutely! you get to explore a wide range of theater topics, and it's exciting to hear from a new professor every week and get to know a large portion of the TAPS faculty
